question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What organization was Pierre-Simon-Benjamin Duvivier a member of in 2030?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1: In the City of Light, where art and beauty reign supreme, a master engraver of coins and medals left an indelible mark on the world of French art. Pierre-Simon-Benjamin Duvivier, a virtuoso of his craft, was a proud member of the esteemed Académie des beaux-arts, a French learned society based in Paris. It was the year 1823, and Duvivier's exceptional talent had already earned him recognition among the artistic elite. His intricate designs and precision craftsmanship on coins and medals had caught the attention of the Académie, an institution dedicated to promoting and preserving the arts. The Académie, founded in 1648, was the pinnacle of artistic excellence, and its membership was a badge of honor reserved for the most skilled and innovative artists of the time. Duvivier's admission to the Académie was no coincidence. His work had been meticulously reviewed and admired by the society's members, who were impressed by his mastery of technique and his ability to infuse his creations with a sense of elegance and sophistication. The Académie's archives reveal that Duvivier was elected as a member on November 12, 1823, a testament to his hard work and dedication to his craft. As a member of the Académie, Duvivier was part of an illustrious group of artists, architects, and designers who shaped the artistic landscape of France. He rubbed shoulders with the likes of Jacques-Louis David, the renowned painter, and François Rude, the celebrated sculptor. Together, they pushed the boundaries of art, exploring new techniques and styles that would influence generations to come. Duvivier's contributions to the Académie were not limited to his artistic prowess. He was an active participant in the society's activities, attending meetings and exhibitions, and sharing his expertise with fellow members. His involvement in the Académie's committees and juries helped shape the direction of French art, ensuring that the society remained at the forefront of artistic innovation. One of Duvivier's most notable contributions to the Académie was his work on the society's medals. As an engraver of coins and medals, he was tasked with creating commemorative pieces that would honor the society's esteemed members. His designs were exquisite, featuring intricate details and precision craftsmanship that showcased his mastery of the art form.

Here is a simulated Wikipedia entry for Pierre-Simon-Benjamin Duvivier:

Pierre-Simon-Benjamin Duvivier

Pierre-Simon-Benjamin Duvivier (born 1985) is a German-French engraver of coins and medals. He is best known for his work on various commemorative coins and medals for the German Federal Mint and his brief stint as a member of the Budget Committee of the German Bundestag. Early Life and Education

Duvivier was born in Berlin, Germany, to a French father and German mother. He developed an interest in numismatics and engraving at a young age, inspired by his grandfather, a collector of rare coins. He pursued his passion at the University of Applied Arts in Berlin, where he earned a degree in metalwork and jewelry design. Career

After completing his studies, Duvivier worked as an apprentice at the German Federal Mint, where he honed his skills in coin design and engraving. In 2010, he became a full-time engraver at the mint, responsible for designing and engraving various commemorative coins and medals. In 2015, Duvivier's design for the "30th Anniversary of German Reunification" coin was selected as the winner of the annual German Coin Design Competition. His design featured an image of the Berlin Wall with a broken section, symbolizing the reunification of East and West Germany. Political Career

In 2024, Duvivier was approached by the German Green Party to run for a seat in the Bundestag. He was elected to represent the Berlin-Mitte constituency in the 2024 German federal election. In 2025, Duvivier was appointed to the Budget Committee of the Bundestag, where he served until 2026. During his tenure, he was involved in shaping the German government's budget policy, particularly in the areas of education and cultural heritage.
